decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.	Reason:  As required  by Section 91 of  the Town  and Country Planning  Act  1990,  as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

The development hereby approved shall be carried out in accordance with the materials specified on the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority.	Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Before the beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted, the second floor side (east) window serving a stair landing and the dormer window serving an ensuite bathroom as shown on the approved drawings shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable.  Any part below that level shall be fitted with, and retained in, obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3. Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Officer ReportIntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Section 38(6) of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004 states that planning applications must be determined in accordance with the development plan unless material considerations indicate otherwise.The development plan for the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames comprises the following documents:- The London Plan 2021- The South London Waste Plan 2012 - The LDF Core Strategy 2012- The Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008Application SiteThe application site is occupied by a two storey semi detached building.    ProposalThe application seeks permission for the erection of single storey side/rear extension.There is a TPO applicable to a Maple tree in the rear north eastern corner of the property.Consultation9 properties were notified of the proposal. 1 representation was received, objecting to the proposal.The objections raised concerns in relation to the following:Access and traffic issuesCar parking issuesFumesEffects on treesExcessive height and bulkInappropriate design and layoutLoss of light/sunlightIncompatibility of useThe above are all material planning considerations however matters relating to traffic, car parking and fumes in relation to a single storey extension are usually temporary, limited to the construction period. Notwithstanding, the effects are considered below.Any issues with regards to land disputes / land leases are civil matters - where they align with amenity considerations they are addressed below.With regard to the compatibility of use, officers note this is a single residential dwelling seeking to continue the residential use of the property with some enlargements of existing living spaces.  This is reflected in the proposed layout. All other matters relating to amenity will be addressed in the neighbouring amenities part of this report.Tree and landscape officer: No objections or concerns in relation to the proposed development.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers.Character and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The proposed side extension would infill part of the open area alongside the existing rear extension of the property 6.08m deep x 2.42m wide (to integrate and align with the rear extension). The property would then narrow to an existing rear extension which would be reconfigured internally with the replacement of existing windows to the side and rear elevations. The side extension would have a pitched roof design 2.39m in height at the eaves, up to 3.27m as it connects to the rear elevation of the existing dwelling with 3 x rooflights. Glazed doors are proposed to the rear elevation, and two large windows to the side elevation. In relation to neighbouring properties, the side extension would maintain and continue the building line from the front part of the existing building, and be setback from the boundary with No.46 Coombe Gardens. The proposed works would maintain the existing building line and height as it relates to No.42 Coombe Gardens.The proposed external materials including brick walls, roof tiles, window and door finishes are all considered satisfactory.Having regard to the above, officers consider that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the area.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.There will be no changes to the building line or height of the application property as it relates to No.42 Coombe Gardens. To the opposite side, the extension will continue the building line of the main building and maintain a setback from the boundary with No.46 Coombe Gardens ensuring the protection of daylight and sunlight and outlook from this property. Windows to the side elevation of the extension will be obscured (by condition)  to ensure privacy is maintained. Having regard to the above, officers consider that the impact of the proposed development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers would be acceptable have regard to all relevant factors. ConclusionHaving regard to the above, officers consider the proposal to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole. In the absence of any other material considerations which indicate that permission should be refused, officers conclude that planning permission should be granted.Background PapersIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 The Plans / Drawings / Documents submitted with the application are available on the Council's website.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal
